index.meta_description: SARIF output, AWS SSM validation, shell-script env files, and CI/CD-ready scanning for your environment variables.
index.hero_h1:
Validate your env vars.
Ship with confidence.
index.hero_sub: Catch missing environment variables before they hit production. SARIF reports, AWS SSM validation, and smart fallback detection — all in one CLI tool.
index.features_sub: A complete toolkit for environment variable hygiene — from local dev to production CI.
index.feat_sarif_p: Generate machine-readable SARIF reports that plug directly into the GitHub Security tab — zero configuration needed.
index.feat_aws_p: Validate that every env var exists in Parameter Store or Secrets Manager before you deploy.
index.feat_shell_p: Parse export statements from shell scripts and include them in your scan automatically.
index.feat_fallback_p: Automatically distinguishes between warnings (vars with fallbacks) and errors (vars that will crash). Prioritise what matters.
index.feat_ci_p: The --ci flag exits non-zero on errors, making it a drop-in gate for any pipeline.
index.feat_strict_p: Surface every env var reference — including known runtime vars — for full visibility when you need it.
index.tiers_sub: Free nails the basics. Pro is for teams that need SARIF, AWS validation, and shell-script driven env sources.
index.tier_source_pro: Distributed via npm with protected sources
index.tier_shell_pro: `envFiles` lets you import reusable `.sh` snippets like `set-env.sh`
index.tier_aws_pro: `--aws`, `--aws-deep`, profiles, and prefixes for SSM + Secrets
index.tier_highlight: Stick with the free edition when you only need local .env analysis. Go Pro when you want CI-ready outputs, AWS guardrails, or the ability to load environment variables from curated shell scripts that the rest of your org already uses.
index.compare_free_sub: Great for quickly checking the obvious env blocks inside serverless.yml.
index.compare_free_2_p: Checks each function block for custom values before deploy.
index.compare_free_3_p: Stops before the AWS resources section, so custom ECS/Lambda containers and deeper secret references stay invisible.
index.compare_pro_sub: Purpose-built for teams that rely on AWS infrastructure-as-code and want total coverage.
index.compare_pro_1_p: Sweeps the provider block, each function, and the AWS resources section so ECS, Lambda, and Step Functions containers stay honest.
index.compare_pro_2_p: Understands chained Secrets Manager values (think aurora.host) and confirms the actual key that will load in prod.
index.compare_pro_3_p: Resolves SSM paths, understands stages, and tells you which resource owns a missing variable so fixes are fast.
index.how_sub: From install to insight in seconds.
index.how_step1_p: One npm install and you're set — global or project-local.
index.how_step2_p: Drop a .envguardrc.json in your project root or add options to package.json.
index.how_step3_p: Run envguard scan. It statically analyses every file in your project.
index.how_step4_p: Errors and warnings are reported — fix, ignore, or push straight to GitHub Security via SARIF.
index.hooks_title: Catch env issues before commit or push
index.hooks_sub: EnvGuard Pro can install Git hooks that automatically run envguard scan --ci before each commit or push, catching environment variable issues before they reach your repository.
index.hooks_li1: The hook script runs npx envguard scan --ci (plus any flags passed via --scan-args) automatically before the Git operation.
index.hooks_li2: If issues are found, the operation is blocked and the hook prints the scan output.
index.hooks_li3: To bypass the hook for a single operation, use the standard Git escape hatch: --no-verify.
index.hooks_note: Note: uninstall-hook will only remove hooks that were created by EnvGuard. If a hook exists but was written by another tool, it will be left untouched.
index.scan_title: Scan output you can actually act on
index.scan_sub: EnvGuard doesn't just list every variable — it tells you which ones will crash and which ones are safely handled.
index.scan_li1: Errors — vars that are missing and have no fallback. These will crash at runtime.
index.scan_li2: Warnings — vars that are missing but have a fallback defined. Low priority.
index.scan_li3: Unused & skipped — variables defined but never referenced, plus known runtime vars like AWS_REGION filtered out by default.
index.aws_title: Validate against the source of truth
index.aws_sub: Don't guess. Confirm that every parameter and secret your app needs actually exists in AWS — before deploy day.
index.aws_secrets_p: Validates top-level secrets and, with --aws-deep, checks nested JSON keys too.
index.aws_param_p: Auto-discovers SSM paths from your serverless.yml or uses a prefix for fallback scanning.
index.aws_profile_p: Picks up AWS_REGION and profile settings automatically — or override via flags.
index.sarif_sub: One flag. Machine-readable output that plugs directly into GitHub's Security tab for compliance tracking — no extra tooling required.
index.sarif_li1: Each missing variable becomes a SARIF rule with a precise file + line location.
index.sarif_li2: Errors and warnings map to different severity levels — GitHub surfaces them accordingly.
index.sarif_li3: Drop into any CI step: --format sarif --output results.sarif
index.sarif_gallery_h: What it looks like in GitHub Security
index.sarif_gallery_sub: Real SARIF views from GitHub — click any image to zoom.
index.trust_sub: Pro is a closed-source extension of an open-source core. Here's exactly what that means.
index.trust_open_p: The core scanner is fully open at github.com/szlaskidaniel/envguard. Audit it freely.
index.trust_telemetry_p: Zero data collection. No analytics, no phone-home. The only network calls are explicit AWS SDK operations when you opt in.
index.trust_scope_p: Published under the @danielszlaski npm scope with verified ownership.
index.trust_sandbox_p: Not comfortable? Audit network traffic or run it in a sandboxed environment. Full flexibility is yours.
index.faq_sub: Quick answers to common questions about EnvGuard Pro.
index.faq_q1: Is EnvGuard Pro intended for beginners?
index.faq_a1: This tool is intended for professionals. Remember to back up your data before using it.
index.faq_q2: What AWS IAM permissions are required for --aws / --aws-deep?
index.faq_a2:
Required IAM Permissions:

  • ssm:GetParameter — for SSM Parameter Store validation (--aws)
  • secretsmanager:DescribeSecret — for Secrets Manager validation (--aws)
  • secretsmanager:GetSecretValue — required for --aws-deep (reads the secret JSON to validate nested keys like host and port)

Use --aws-deep to validate that the referenced nested keys actually exist within the secret JSON.

We do not store or log retrieved secret values — they are used only in-memory to check presence and report validation results.
index.faq_q3: Why is the source code obfuscated?
index.faq_a3: EnvGuard Pro is distributed with obfuscated sources to protect intellectual property while keeping full functionality. The open-source core is available on GitHub.
index.faq_q4: Does EnvGuard Pro collect telemetry or send data anywhere?
index.faq_a4: No. There is no telemetry or data collection. The only network calls are explicit AWS SDK operations when you opt in via --aws / --aws-deep.
index.faq_q5: How do I configure EnvGuard Pro?
index.faq_a5:
Use .envguardrc.json (or package.json) for config. CLI flags override configuration values.

Common overrides:

  • --strict to enable strict mode regardless of config
  • --no-detect-fallbacks to treat missing vars as errors (ignore fallbacks)
  • --env-files set-env.sh to add shell env sources without editing config
index.faq_a6: Fallback detection distinguishes between warnings (env vars used with fallbacks) and errors (env vars that will crash when missing). Disable it with --no-detect-fallbacks or set detectFallbacks to false in config.
index.faq_q7: How do I use EnvGuard Pro in CI?
index.faq_a7:
Use --ci to integrate EnvGuard Pro into CI/CD. It sets the exit code so your pipeline can fail fast.

What happens with --ci:

  • Exits with code 1 if any missing environment variables (errors) are found
  • Exits with code 1 if any AWS resources are missing (when using --aws)
  • Exits with code 0 if only warnings or info-level issues are found

Examples:

  • envguard scan --ci
  • envguard scan --ci --strict (fail on any issue including warnings)
  • envguard scan --ci --aws (include AWS validation)
  • envguard scan --ci --no-detect-fallbacks (treat fallbacks as errors)
index.faq_q8: Can it scan env vars defined in shell scripts?
index.faq_a8: Yes. Use envFiles in .envguardrc.json or pass --env-files to include export-based variables from shell scripts like set-env.sh.
index.faq_q9: How do I generate a SARIF report for GitHub Security?
index.faq_a9: Run envguard scan --format sarif --output results.sarif and upload the SARIF to GitHub Security in your CI pipeline.
index.cta_h: Ready to stop guessing about your env vars?
index.cta_p: Install in seconds. Catch issues in minutes. Ship with the confidence that your environment is solid.

installation.meta_description: Install EnvGuard Pro via npm (global CLI) or from a private tarball (.tgz) in your project. Step-by-step commands and verification.
installation.hero_h1:
Install EnvGuard Pro.
From a package tarball.
installation.hero_sub: EnvGuard Pro is distributed as a .tgz package you install into your project. This page includes copy-paste commands and a quick verification checklist.
installation.project_sub: Use this when EnvGuard Pro is provided as a downloadable archive from a private GitHub repository.
installation.step1_p: Download the .tgz archive from the private repository (requires access).
installation.step2_p: Keep the archive in your project so installs are reproducible (and work offline).
installation.step3_p: Point npm at the local archive to add it to node_modules.
installation.tip: Tip: npm tarballs commonly use the .tgz extension (still a .tar.gz under the hood).
installation.example_layout: Example layout and commands (adjust the filename/version you received):
installation.verify_sub: Run these commands from your project root. If your setup exposes envguard instead of envguard-pro, the commands are interchangeable.
installation.trouble_sub: Common install issues and quick fixes.
installation.trouble_cmd_p: Use npx envguard-pro (or npx envguard) from your project root, or add an npm script, instead of calling a global binary.
installation.trouble_perm_p: Make sure your project directory is user-writable and avoid running npm with elevated permissions.
installation.trouble_node_p: Upgrade Node.js to a modern LTS if you see syntax or runtime errors during install or execution.

privacy.intro: At EnvGuard Pro, we believe in privacy by design. We are developers, and we understand that your environment variables and secrets are sensitive. This Privacy Policy explains how we handle—or rather, do not handle—your data.
privacy.telemetry_p1: We do not collect usage data, telemetry, or analytics from the Software.
privacy.telemetry_li1: Local Processing: The Software runs locally on your machine. All logic, parsing, and file handling happen on your device.
privacy.telemetry_li2: Direct Cloud Connection: When the Software verifies secrets (e.g., via AWS SSM or Secret Manager), it connects directly from your machine to your cloud provider's API.
privacy.aws_li1: --aws (default): checks existence only; never reads secret values.
privacy.aws_li2: --aws-deep: fetches secret values into local memory to validate nested keys; values are not stored to disk or transmitted.
privacy.no_phone_home: No "Phone Home": Your credentials, secrets, environment variables, and configuration files are never sent to our servers. We do not have access to your AWS keys or secrets.
privacy.data_intro: We only process data necessary to facilitate your purchase and provide support.
privacy.data_li1: Purchase Data: When you buy EnvGuard Pro, our reseller (Lemon Squeezy) collects your billing information. As the developer, I receive your email address and name to verify the license and send product updates (e.g., new .tgz versions). I do not have access to your credit card details.
privacy.data_li2: Support Inquiries: If you email us for support, we will use your email address solely to reply to your inquiry.
privacy.third_li1: Lemon Squeezy: Acts as our Merchant of Record. Their privacy policy applies during the checkout process.
privacy.third_li2: GitHub Pages: This website is hosted on GitHub Pages. GitHub may collect technical logs (e.g., IP addresses) for security and reliability purposes.
privacy.updates_p: We may update this Privacy Policy to reflect changes in our software (e.g., if we introduce an auto-update feature). Any changes will be posted on this page.
privacy.contact_p: If you have questions about this policy, please Contact me

terms.payments_li2: Refund Policy: Due to the nature of digital downloadable products (distribution via .tgz files), all sales are final. We do not offer refunds once the software has been downloaded, except where required by consumer protection law.

terms.liability_p1: IMPORTANT: The Software interacts with your cloud infrastructure (e.g., AWS SSM). You are solely responsible for backing up your data and configurations.
terms.liability_p2: IN NO EVENT SHALL THE LICENSOR BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES, OR OTHER LIABILITY (INCLUDING DATA LOSS, SYSTEM OUTAGE, OR FINANCIAL LOSS), WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT, OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM, OUT OF, OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE. THE LICENSOR’S TOTAL LIABILITY SHALL NOT EXCEED THE AMOUNT PAID BY YOU FOR THE LICENSE.
terms.updates_p: We may provide updates to the Software at our discretion. We reserve the right to modify these Terms at any time. Continued use of the Software constitutes acceptance of the modified Terms.
terms.contact_p: For support or licensing inquiries, please Contact me
